body: It should be easy to add.. I'll have a go and if it goes well it will be in our bugfix release 1.6.1 very soon.

If you could have a look at the tests I've written and let me know if there are any other weird cases for these combinators, that would be great. since its just adding a new type of selector combinator, I don't see that it needs any more advanced tests combining it with other features, it should just work.

repository.name: less4j
repository.description: Less language is an extension of css and less4j compiles it into regular css. Less adds several dynamic features into css: variables, expressions, nested rules, and so on. Less was designed to be compatible with css and any correct css file is also correct less file.

body:
Sorry, I missed your post about the test cases.
LGTM!

issue.title: Parent Selectors should have targets
issue.body:
When creating a Parent Selector rule, everything before the `&` gets prepended to the outermost scope.  

The feature could be greatly improved by allowing for "parent targeting", where you could apply the parent selector to a specific parent (in the case where you have deeply nested selectors).

The syntax for this feature is probably the biggest hindrance, so I would love to start a discussion on the possibilities.

issue.title: support for /deep/ and ::shadow
issue.body: With custom elements landed in Chrome beta and shadow dom in Chrome stable, the need for `::shadow` and `/deep/` syntax is becoming real. I don't like the `/deep/` syntax, it's ugly as sin, but also rather important for overriding styling inside a shadow dom element, and right now less crashes when it encounters it, so: feature request for ::shadow and /deep/ support =)

issue.title: Less throws an error with the ">>>" combinator
issue.body:
Eg, 

```
ParseError: Unrecognised input in path\to\less\main.less on line 25, column 7:
24
25 html >>> .materialblue {
26
```

However, this is valid.

See:
- https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Web_Components/Shadow_DOM
- https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=446051
- https://w3c.github.io/webcomponents/spec/shadow/#composed-trees
- http://dev.w3.org/csswg/css-scoping/#deep-combinator

This should be correctly passed through.
